nodes.text: Machine learning classifiers (KNN, Random Forest, SVM) can improve early detection of lung cancer from CT images
Early detection of lung cancer is critical because late-stage diagnosis has low cure rates and high mortality
Training and evaluation used the LIDC-IDRI CT image dataset plus validation samples from AHRC and AIMS hospitals
Image preprocessing included resizing, normalization and filters such as CLAHE, Wiener, adaptive Gaussian, Gaussian and Gabor to reduce noise and standardize inputs
Classifiers evaluated were K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Random Forest
Training procedure: dataset of 500 images, 70% training 30% testing split, feature extraction from downscaled images, and 5-fold cross-validation used for performance estimation
SVM classifier achieved average accuracy 95.06% across 5-fold cross-validation with high precision, recall and F1 scores reported per fold
KNN classifier achieved average accuracy 86.89% across 5 folds with reported precision, recall and F1 metrics
Random Forest classifier achieved average accuracy 81.96% across 5 folds with reported precision, recall and F1 metrics
Performance tables show per-fold TPR, FPR, precision, recall, F1-score and accuracy for each classifier and report ROC-AUC values above 0.99 per class
SVM outperforms KNN and Random Forest on this task, attributed to its ability to handle high-dimensional features and complex decision boundaries
The proposed image-processing and machine-learning pipeline can provide accurate and timely lung cancer diagnosis, potentially aiding clinicians
Study limitations include a relatively small sample of 500 images and limited demographic diversity; future work will expand dataset size and diversity to improve reliability
